722115f-a.text:
Park Ave., east side, south from 41st Street, during the construction of the Lexington Ave. Subway. The 41st Street pedestrian overpass has been temporarily taken down. On the right, appears a portion o the Murray
Hill Hotel.
April 5, 1901.

722192f-a.text:
Grand Union Hotel, Park Avenue, east side, from 4lst to 42nd Streets, also showing the new Grand Central Station and the old spur of the Third Avenue Elevated, which will be taken down
in 1944.
The Grand Union was to a great extent built by acquistion of old houses in the block, intervening walls being knocked out and rooms remodelled. The whole is shown shortly before demolition. Compare this with later pictures of the same block.
1914.
Gift of E.M. Jenks.

722561f-a.title: Manhattan: Pershing Square - 41st Street (East)
722561f-a.text:
Pershing Square (Park Avenue), east side, from East 41st (right) to 42nd (left), Street's, showing the Grand Union Hotel of the 1890's. This structure was demolished in the Summer of 1914, and was later replaced with the present Pershing Square Building. The 40th-42nd Street area acquired this designation in honor of the commander in Chief of the American Expeditionary Force in France about this time. It was originally Fourth Avenue, a section of which was changed to Park Avenue.
About 1914
Gift of Urbrock Collection

722562f-a.title: Manhattan: Pershing Square - 41st Street (East)
722562f-a.text:
Pershing Square (Park Avenue), east side, from East 41st (right) to 42nd (left) Street's, showing the Grand Union Hotel of the 1890's. This structure was removed in the Summer of 1914. Upon this site was erected the Pershing Square Building. Note the Architects Building on the right margin; the absence of the automobile viaduct over the Avenue; and the old "El" spur on 42nd Street.
About 1914
H. N. Tiemann, photo
Gift of Urbrock Collection

722189f.text:
Park Avenue, west side, from 41st to 442nd Streets, the side entrance
to the Hotel Belmont, at Pershing Square.
Probably late 1918.

722193f.text:
Park Avenue, east side, from 41st to 42nd Streets, on Pershing Sduare, where the Grand Union Hotel stood until June, 1914, showing the new Grand Central Station ano the recently commpleted Hotel Commodore on the north side of 42nd Street, also the old elevated spur used until 1923 as a shuttle to the Third Avenue line. The covered stairways in the vacant lot are entrances to the express station of the new east side Interborough Subway,
which was opened in the summer of 1918.
About 1919.
0ift of E. M. Jenks.

722190f.text:
Pershing Square, Park Avenue from 4lst to 42nd Streets, looking west at the Hotel Belmont (1906-31) from the vacant lot where the Grand Union Hotel used to stand and where the Pershing Square building will be erected. The name Pershing Square, after General Pershing, commander of the American Expeditionary Force, was applied to this block about the time of the Armistice.
The Pershing Square viaduct, shown here, conducted automobile traffic from Park Avenue and 40th Street across 42nd Street and around the left side of the Grand Central Station to Vanderbilt Avenue and 45th Street. As shown here it is quite new. The covered stairway coming up out of the vacant lot in the foreground is an entrance to the new Lexington Avenue Interborough Subway, opened in the summer of 1918. On the S.W. corner of 4lst Street may be seen part of the old Murray Hill Hotel; and west on 42nd Street the Hotel Manhattan on the N. W. corner of Madison Avenue, later to be remodelled into an office building and uptown office for the National City Bank. The small building on the N. E. corner of Madison Avenue and 42nd Street is shortly to be demolished and replaced by the Liggett Drug building.
About 1920.

within two years.

722566f-c.title: Manhattan: Pershing Square - 41st Street
722566f-c.text:
(1)
Pershing Square, (Park Ave). west side, from East 42nd to 4lst Streets. Also shown is the Murray Hill Hotel, at No. 112 Park Ave.,wes. side, from East 41st to 40th Streets. Building shown under demolition is the Hotel Belmont. This view is as seen from the Graybar Building and across Grand Central Station; southward. Note the raised vehicular viaduct at this point.
April 28, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, showing mainly the Hotel Belmont.
April 28, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.

722563f.text:
Pershing Square (Park Ave.), west side, from East 41st (left) to 42nd (right) Streets, showing the Belmont Hotel. This building, erected about 1906, was demolished in 1931. The site, today (1937) is stkll
vacant.
Prior to 1931.
International News Photos.

722560f-a.title: Manhattan: Pershing Square - 41st Street (East)
722560f-a.text:
Pershing SQuare, at the N.E. corner of East 41st Street, as seen viewing eastward on 41st Street, from a point just west of the west side of the Square. Building shown, is the Pershing Scuare Building. Across its roof apoears portions of the Chanin and Chrysler Buildings. Note the Vehicular viaduct at this point.
1936.
W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Writers Project.
